docs.lead_paragraph: The following reports compile all significant security incidents confirmed by New York Times reporters and stringers throughout Afghanistan. It is necessarily incomplete as many local officials refuse to confirm casualty information.

docs.abstract: If the past teaches us anything, it will happen one day. In fact, the process might have already started.
docs.snippet: If the past teaches us anything, it will happen one day. In fact, the process might have already started.
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook earned more than $5 billion in profit last quarter, and yet it has spent much of 2018 trapped in a defensive crouch. This year was defined by brutal press coverage, internal strife, executive departures and unwanted attention from authorities. The company stands accused of various offenses: degrading politics; empowering despots; leaving users vulnerable to abuse; abusing its users’ data for profit. It is in a constant state of crisis such that its executives’ responses to scandals end up becoming scandals themselves.

headline.main: What Happens When Facebook Goes the Way of Myspace?
headline.print_headline: What Happens When Facebook Goes the Way of Myspace?

docs.abstract: It’s less infantile than you’d think. Like daydreams, playing with stuffed animals offers pure delight — a chance to doodle with your emotions.
docs.snippet: It’s less infantile than you’d think. Like daydreams, playing with stuffed animals offers pure delight — a chance to doodle with your emotions.
docs.lead_paragraph: Every night I spend a few minutes catching up with my friends. I saw them during the day — maybe one rode along with me on my long commute, or relaxed nearby while I worked from home. But this last check-in closes the evening nicely. I talk to them, imagine what they might be thinking. I pick them up and play out their whims.

docs.abstract: The Bud Light mascot embodied the entitled recklessness of being young, white and rich. Admire him without guilt — you can’t cancel a dog.
docs.snippet: The Bud Light mascot embodied the entitled recklessness of being young, white and rich. Admire him without guilt — you can’t cancel a dog.
docs.lead_paragraph: Senior year of college, whenever I was stressed, I liked to take a long, hot shower with an ice-cold beer. Shower beers became a cheap, relaxing vice; it’s how I began to appreciate the swill my roommates kept in our refrigerator. (Taking a wineglass into the bathroom just felt crass.) Soon, just as “being really into beer” became an entire personality for some of our fellow Connecticut-country-club liberal-arts classmates, “ironically being really into cheap beer” became mine. I began going out of my way to request the occasional PBR or Heineken at a party or on a date, just to see the wince that skipped across a person’s face when I dramatically insisted it was “the good stuff.”

docs.abstract: When my brother and I still had identification cards with the word “alien” on them, barbecue chicken pizza helped us feel at home.
docs.snippet: When my brother and I still had identification cards with the word “alien” on them, barbecue chicken pizza helped us feel at home.
docs.lead_paragraph: The room my brother and I shared when we first moved to the United States was small and dark, with an off-putting smell that emanated from a noisy air-conditioner. It wasn’t ideal, but we’d lived in small spaces before. Atlanta was something else — hot and humid, coursing with wide highways that neither one of us was old enough to drive along. That summer, bored and unsupervised, we’d sit on the curb in the parking lot for as long as we could take the heat, wanting school to start, and dreading it. Making fun of the whingy American accents, and wanting our own.

headline.main: I Ate Mall Pizza and Fell in Love With America
headline.print_headline: How I Fell in Love With America

docs.abstract: The online world is an interactive museum of humiliation, bad faith and gross memes. This is why we need parrots trolling cats.
docs.snippet: The online world is an interactive museum of humiliation, bad faith and gross memes. This is why we need parrots trolling cats.
docs.lead_paragraph: The internet is, famously, terrible. Try it sometime; you’ll see. It is designed to coax all of your neural pathways open and then, while they are in a state of ecstatic receptivity, to dump horrible things into them. You hardly even need to click: These days, much of the badness is automatic. It sprouts at the edges of otherwise innocuous pages. You will be enjoying yourself, and then all of a sudden you’ll be watching video of a conspiracy monger screaming at people in a fried-chicken restaurant or of a basketball player snapping his leg in half or of a sprinting athlete crashing onto a track, midstride, because his genitals have spilled out of his shorts. The online world is an interactive museum of humiliation, sadism, greed, bleak news, bad faith and gross memes.

headline.main: Animal Videos Are How We Escape the Internet (While on the Internet)

docs.abstract: To “glean” means to pick grain out of a threshed field — or, these days, knowledge from the air around us.
docs.snippet: To “glean” means to pick grain out of a threshed field — or, these days, knowledge from the air around us.
docs.lead_paragraph: — From the short story “The Ones Who Stay and Fight,” in the collection “How Long ’Til Black Future Month?” (Orbit, 2018, Page 9), by the Hugo Award-winning writer N.K. Jemisin.

docs.abstract: Hair loss is often associated with wisdom — and for good reason.
docs.snippet: Hair loss is often associated with wisdom — and for good reason.
docs.lead_paragraph: Two weeks into my freshman year of college, I noticed, after showering in the communal bathroom, dozens of hairs strewn across the basin of the sink. Distantly, I had known this moment would come, that I would join the ranks of bald men, but I had not expected it would come so soon. As a boy, I eyed my tonsured uncles warily, wincing at their scalps, revolted by the way their domes gleamed wetly on torrid summer days. But deep down I knew my repulsion was self-directed — that one day I would end up like them.

headline.main: The Lives They Loved: Louvic Cabrera
The Lives They Loved: Jay McKain
